title: Naaman's Healing
shortSummary: This chapter recounts the healing of Naaman, a Syrian commander afflicted with leprosy, through the prophet Elisha’s instructions. It highlights themes of faith, obedience, and God's sovereignty, while also warning against greed through Gehazi's disobedience.
timeline: c. 9th century BC - During the reigns of the kings of Israel and Syria

keyCharacters.name: Naaman
keyCharacters.description: Commander of the Syrian army, a mighty and honorable man afflicted with leprosy who seeks healing.

keyCharacters.name: Elisha
keyCharacters.description: The prophet of God in Israel who instructs Naaman on how to be healed.

keyCharacters.name: The Israelite Maid
keyCharacters.description: A captive servant girl from Israel who encourages Naaman’s wife to seek the prophet’s help.

keyCharacters.name: Gehazi
keyCharacters.description: Elisha’s servant who greedily accepts gifts from Naaman and is punished with leprosy.

definitions.definition: A chronic skin disease mentioned in the Bible, often symbolizing uncleanness and separation from the community.
An ancient unit of weight and money; a large sum of silver or gold used as currency.
A messenger chosen by God to deliver His word and perform His will.
A type of sacrifice in the Old Testament where an animal was wholly consumed by fire as an act of worship.

outline.heading: Naaman’s Condition and the Israelite Maid’s Advice
outline.description: Naaman, a respected Syrian commander afflicted with leprosy, is introduced along with a captive Israelite maid who suggests he seek healing from the prophet in Samaria, setting the stage for divine intervention.

outline.heading: Naaman’s Request and Israel’s King’s Reaction
outline.description: Naaman brings a letter and gifts to the king of Israel requesting healing, but the king is distressed, thinking the request is a provocation; Elisha reassures the king and invites Naaman to come to him.

outline.heading: Elisha’s Instructions and Naaman’s Initial Rebellion
outline.description: Elisha instructs Naaman to wash seven times in the Jordan River, but Naaman is angry and reluctant, expecting a dramatic healing ritual instead.

outline.heading: Naaman’s Obedience and Healing
outline.description: Encouraged by his servants, Naaman obeys and is miraculously healed, acknowledging the God of Israel as the one true God and offering gifts which Elisha refuses.

outline.heading: Gehazi’s Greed and Punishment
outline.description: Gehazi, Elisha’s servant, deceitfully accepts gifts from Naaman and is struck with leprosy as a consequence, illustrating the seriousness of greed and disobedience.

application: Trust God’s instructions even when they seem simple or unimpressive, as true healing and blessing come through obedience to Him.
Recognize and honor the sovereignty of God alone, acknowledging Him as the source of all deliverance and healing.
Reject greed and dishonesty, understanding that God’s blessings are not to be exploited for personal gain.
Encourage others in faith, just as the Israelite maid did, demonstrating the impact of godly witness.

keyVerses.text: Then went he down, and dipped himself seven times in Jordan, according to the saying of the man of God: and his flesh came again like unto the flesh of a little child, and he was clean.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the power of obedience and God’s miraculous healing through simple faith.

keyVerses.text: And he returned to the man of God, he and all his company, and came, and stood before him: and he said, Behold, now I know that there is no God in all the earth, but in Israel: now therefore, I pray thee, take a blessing of thy servant.
keyVerses.significance: Naaman’s confession acknowledges the one true God, underscoring the chapter’s theme of God’s supremacy.

keyVerses.text: The leprosy therefore of Naaman shall cleave unto thee, and unto thy seed for ever. And he went out from his presence a leper as white as snow.
keyVerses.significance: This verse serves as a solemn warning against greed and deceit, showing the consequences of disobedience.
